citation.article-title: Description of Microbacterium foliorum sp. nov. and Microbacterium phyllosphaerae sp. nov., isolated from the phyllosphere of grasses and the surface litter after mulching the sward, and reclassification of Aureobacterium resistens (Funke et al. 1998) as Microbacterium resistens comb. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Microbacterium phyllosphaerae sp. nov.
Microbacterium phyllosphaerae (phyl.lo.sphae'rae. Gr. n. phyllon leaf ; Gr. fem. n. sphaira ball, sphere; M.L. gen. fem. n. phyllosphaerae of the phyllosphere)
The morphological and physiological properties are as described for M. foliorum, but the hydrolysis of Tween 80, casein and starch varies between strains.
Acid production from bgentiobiose, as well as from rhamnose, is positive for all strains.
Acid production is strain-dependent for L-arabinose, inositol, xylitol and D-xylose.
Oxidative acid production from glucose, tested with API 20NE, is positive for almost all strains.
The major menaquinones are MK-12, MK-11 and MK-10.
The predominant cellular fatty acids are 12-methyl tetradecanoic acid, 14-methyl pentadecanoic acid, 13-methyl tetradecanoic acid and 14-methyl hexadecanoic acid.
The DNA G­C composition for the type strain is 64 mol%.
The peptidoglycan is of the B2β (L-homoserine)-D-Glu→Gly→D-Orn type, with glycolyl residues.
The cell-wall sugars are galactose and rhamnose.
Isolated from the phyllosphere of grasses and from the litter layer after mulching of the sward.
